overview_of_class: In many colonial contexts, the pre-colonial has been cast as outside of history. And yet there are places where individuals and their lives have survived the oblivion of history and where something of their lived experience can be recovered. These places indicate productive sites of knowing not only about the small histories of the past, but how these speak to, and elucidate, relations of power and aspects of global history. While this course will focus specifically on an archive assembled in the 1870s and 1880s in colonial South Africa (the Bleek and Lloyd Archive), comprising thousands of pages of interviews with several prisoners described at the time as indigenous hunter-gatherers, or "Cape Bushmen" (now known as |xam), and 4 young displaced boys from northern Namibia, it will also be attentive to the importance of thinking about archives in unconventional ways. The course will give students the opportunity to work with primary sources, - including photographs, maps, genealogies and drawings, as well as stories of origin, of conflict with settlers and relationships with animals, of murder, hunting, personal histories, and of times stretching into the pre-colonial past - to consider visual and object sources, and to think about the effect the making of an archive has on the histories it is able to generate.

overview_of_class: Is there such a thing as a resource curse? More than any other part of the world, the Middle East is closely associated with both extreme abundance (oil) and extreme scarcity (water), and with the politics to which competition over these two resources has given rise. Scholars of the Middle East have recently begun to reckon with how the interconnections between people, environment, and natural resources have shaped the region politically, economically, and socially. In this course, we will survey the modern history of the Middle East and consider such things as water management in the late Ottoman period, and the construction of irrigation systems and national water carriers in the 20th century. The course also considers the emergence of the oil industry, and the construction of national, regional, and international systems for resource extraction, refinement, and transport. We will see that the histories of oil and water are intertwined, and figure in all important issues of Middle Eastern society and politics, from labor organizing, gender relations, and forms of rule to geopolitics and the Arab-Israeli conflict

overview_of_class: This seminar will explore the role of non-European peoples and states in the history of the Renaissance, roughly 1300-1650. We will explore European perceptions of the world outside what is traditionally conceived of as Europe, and what impact the interpretations of and relationships with that world had on the early modern period. The seminar will analyze the relationship between Europe and the Ottoman Empire, and how ongoing conflict and coexistence with the Ottomans shaped the Renaissance worldview; we will also discuss the realities and the limits of a shared Mediterranean world. The course will also analyze the significance of the discovery of the New World and what it meant when Europe truly became part of a global system. Should the Ottoman Empire be included as part of the geographic, sociopolitical, and cultural entity traditionally known as Europe? What is the history behind the very concept of East and West, or East versus West as in the dangerous "clash of civilizations" thesis? Themes of empire, warfare, and religion (as well as religious conversion and slavery) will also be addressed, in addition to perceptions of "the other" from both sides of the Mediterranean Sea.

overview_of_class: Packed with volcanos, "little" ice ages, and fierce debates about scientific efforts to model the most irregular of natural phenomenon, this course explores the impact of weather and climate on historical trends in antiquity, the early modern period, and the modern period in Europe, America, and the Globe. It also traces the complicated science and politics of meteorology from the Enlightenment until the twentieth century. Finally, we will spend nearly a third of the course tackling this question: Can historical examples of global climate crises provide any sense of what the future holds, or, crucially, blueprint for public policy?

overview_of_class: This is a course about race, which does not exist. More specifically, we will examine the often violent, social construction of difference in Latin America from the 16th century to the present, focusing primarily on 19th- and 20th-century Mexico and Brazil. Furthermore, this course will investigate the innumerable ways that religion, gender, and class inform what it meant to be a "scrambled Indian," to live in a "racial democracy," and to be "Afro-Mexican." Classes will consist of brief lectures and ample time for (semi-)directed discussions.

overview_of_class: Once decried as the "Me Decade," and dismissed as a period of bad music, bad hair, bad politics, and overall bad taste, historians are beginning to rethink the significance of the 1970s in the broader sweep of American history. This course aims to get students to think about history in scholarly terms but also intends to get students to apply historical thinking to situations beyond the course. As a result, we will examine the work of academic historians as well as primary sources such as essays and novels, movies, and music. We will use the different items of this class to think through some of the broader thematic continuities and shifts of the era and use these facts and examples to construct our own understandings of the era and how it has shaped contemporary American politics, culture, economics, and society. This class will use various episodes and events throughout the 1970s to ask certain questions and hopefully glean worthwhile answers. We will ask ourselves if and how the 1970s dismantled the postwar political consensus? We will also attempt to answer if the language of individual rights and free market ideology that erupted during the 1970s produced a more or less equitable society? How did civil rights, feminism, environmentalism, and the rise of the Christian Right transform American society and politics? Did larger tectonic shifts in the American economy alter political and social coalitions or did it simply reveal underlying rifts and cleavages? Did the culture wars of the 1960s continue into the 1970s? These themes and other conceptual questions will guide our readings and discussions.

overview_of_class: This course explores the role of gender and sexuality in creating, sustaining, and undermining empires in the eighteenth, nineteenth, and twentieth centuries. We will ask how and why controlling the intimate lives of colonizers and colonized became such a fundamental part of the imperial project. How did colonizing and colonized notions of gender and sexuality come into contact and conflict? How did ideas about sexuality shape racial thinking in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries and what was the fallout of this way of thought in the twentieth? How did independence movements harness and alter imperial ideas about gender and sexuality to overthrow colonial powers? Drawing on primary texts as well as historical monographs and the scholarship of gender and sexuality, we will investigate how empires were built around interlocking ideas about sexuality, gender, class, and race.

overview_of_class: What counts as food? Recent debates over the social and environmental consequences of Genetically Modified Organisms (sometimes called ?Frankenfoods'), media buzz over alternative proteins like crickets, and the mainstream popularity of veganism have provoked a critical return to questions of edibility, the agency of our food, and ecological responsibility - all of which challenge normative, Western orientations towards consumption practices. This course examines cultural constructions of appetite and nourishment by asking: What are the processes through which humans have come to view plants and animals as food? How is edibility either celebrated or refused across time, space, and bodies? And most importantly, how are specific worldviews mobilized in understanding human encounters with the things that we eat? Taking Donna Haraway's landmark work "A Cyborg Manifesto" as a point of departure, cultural constructions of edibility will be explored by theorizing the food system as a vital and material force.

overview_of_class: This seminar examines Britain's entry into the twentieth century by way of its experience of the two world wars. We will ask how these two conflicts transformed the United Kingdom from a bastion of Victorian liberalism into a social democracy. The course will proceed chronologically in three parts: the Great War (1914 - 1918), the interwar era (1918 - 1939), and the Second World War (1939 - 1945). These three sections will be bookended by an expository week on British society and government at the dawn of the twentieth century on one side, and a concluding week on the rise of Labour after 1945 and the construction of Britain's welfare state on the other. Along the way, we will focus on historiographical debates about the era's key themes and social transformations, including the nation's gradual political democratization, class relations, the changing position of women in society and politics, the development of a mass commercial leisure culture, and the tensions between rearmament, appeasement, pacifism, and internationalism. We will think carefully about how the major social and political transformations of these thirty years unfolded within the lives of ordinary Britons, how major structural changes in government, economics, and international relations manifested in the texture of everyday life experiences.
